ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Vocab words and patterns for discussing modern issues, practical speaking skills, practice listening and reading Chinese, etc.
Discussing serious topics in Chinese! You also learn about Chinese culture and history

Chinese 150 presents an opportunity to practice skills learned in previous Chinese courses and apply them to topics that are much more interesting/politically relevant (gender equality, finance, religion etc).

I learned how to talk, write, and read about complex topics relevant to modern times. Since the entire class was taught in Chinese, my listening comprehension also improved greatly. I also not only learned grammar and vocabulary, but also learned the differences and similarities between different words and structures and which should be used when.
Advanced Chinese skills. Improved reading, speaking, writing, listening.
New day to day vocabulary, grammar, and historical/cultural knowledge about china.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strenghts: the lectures are extremely helpful, the professors genuinely care and will go out of their way to help their students. The texbook is great 

Weaknesses: I wish we had more discussions instead of language drills, but the profs were responsive to what the students wanted.

The course has a pretty well-defined structure that would be difficult to change, and you do learn a lot. However, I found the textbook to be quite poor; often the pages are unmarked, the distinction between simplified and traditional characters is misleading, and apparently, the information on a lot of topics would be quite incorrect  at least this is what my tutorial instructor said. I also think a lot of the time the audio recordings of the lessons didn't line up with the actual text for each lesson. I think it would be better to have one fewer lesson in this course and be able to spend more time using and learning the grammar, sentence patterns, and how to actually use some of the vocabularies in conversation  there was little to no time for this.

I think there could be a lot more opportunities for constructive feedback. None of my paper feedback gave any actual formative ways to improve on my grade.

One strength of this course was the immense amount of vocabulary, structures, and information about Chinese society that we learned in one semester. All of the stories in the textbook were very interesting and engaging, which made learning the vocabulary easier. Our homework assignments also facilitated a lot of review which made studying for large exams and writing essays more manageable. One weakness of this course was that sometimes deadlines online were different than what was discussed in class and it was hard to tell exactly when things were due. Another weakness is that while characters weren't assigned for homework, we were expected to know them for the exams. Constant character practice was hard to manage with the homework we already had, which meant that most of the character memorizing had to be done very close to the exams.

The course material and the instructors are excellent. However, the pace of the class is a little fast. I would have appreciated more time to feel confident in what I learned before moving onto the next lesson which builds upon the last one. The course seemed to be designed to meet 5 times a week instead of 3. We never had enough time to go over everything we were supposed to and many students (myself included) often felt behind.

Strengths: You learn everything you need to
Weaknesses: Repetitive and some grammar structures could have been explained better
No written assignments yet we got tested on writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, for any student who loves learning Chinese and doesn't mind spending a significant amount of time on the course (you have to make this class your top priority).
Absolutely if you want to study chinese seriously
This course is a great opportunity to continue practicing Mandarin, but unless you really want to continue learning Chinese or are required to take it at this level I wouldn't, it's a lot of work.
I would recommend this course because it really improved my proficiency in Chinese. Many of the political and societal topics I discuss in English, I can now discuss in Chinese.
Yes! I love this course and all the Chinese courses I've taken. However I would caution that the 1 credit rating does not accurately reflect the actual workload required.
If you want to learn Chinese, yes.
If they want to learn chinese, yes!
